Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling Material Microstructure Evolution and Fatigue Life of High Strength Metal Components Produced by Laser Melting Additive Process

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Additive manufacturing can enable industry to produce on-demand parts at a remote site, in space, or in a battlefield, with minimal inventory, delivery time, and tooling cost. It can also enable researchers to explore new material compositions leading to customized novel properties. To ensure quality of components in laser melting (one of the additive manufacturing processes) and reduce the lead time, it is critical to be able to evaluate material microstructure changes in response to the dynamic high thermal gradient in the process, and the strength of constructed materials under static and dynamic loads after the process. This award supports fundamental research to enable modeling and simulation methods that allow for realistic predictions, process design and optimization, and equipment design of laser melting additive process. The obtained knowledge provides the foundation for researchers and manufacturers to engineer new materials in small lot size at low cost by using laser melting additive process. It can also contribute to understanding the behavior of a broad range of materials in laser melting. Research results will enhance current engineering courses, and provide cross-disciplinary training opportunities for graduate students.

The research objectives are to: (1) acquire knowledge on the mechanism of non-equilibrium solidification in laser melting, (2) determine the effects of non-uniform cyclic thermal history due to multilayer construction on microstructure changes, and (3) establish the relationship between the microstructure resulted from laser melting and the material performances. To achieve the first objective, a thermo-mechanical finite element analysis will be constructed to simulate the material addition process of laser melting, a phase-field approach will be created to calculate the time-dependent growth of alloy phase field based on the computed thermal history, and single-pass and multilayer laser melting experiments will be conducted on a medium carbon steel. The correlation between high thermal gradients from computation and the solute trapping phenomenon from experimental observation will be made to reveal the non-equilibrium solidification mechanism. To achieve the second objective, the microstructure evolutions under both single pass and multilayer laser melting processes are compared using the phase field approach, and verified by experiments. Microstructure variations in terms of grain size, phase composition and distribution will be obtained, resulting from different thermal histories of material points. To achieve the third objective, the analytical models for estimating strengths will be established based on the obtained material microstructure, and the fatigue crack initiation life will be estimated based on the minimum energy principle applied when a crack is created along the weakest material point and path.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has enabled modeling and simulation methods that allow for realistic prediction, process design and optimization of laser melting additive processes. The results have contributed to the fundamental understanding of fast solidification process in laser additive manufacturing of metal alloys.

A multi-scale modeling approach was developed to investigate the dendrite morphology, solute redistribution, interdendritic micro-segregation, and stray grain growth during selective laser melting (SLM). The approach consists of (1) meso-scale finite element analysis (FEA) for calculating the temperature field, and (2) micro-scale phase field (PF) method for modeling solidification evolution in the SLM process. It was discovered that the effects of SLM process parameters on various cooling characteristics of the melt pool, including the cooling rate, thermal gradient/solidification rate ratio, and slope of solidification front, are significant. Due to the ultra-fast cooling rate, solute trapping plays a significant role in the solidification process and therefore the interdendritic segregation is alleviated with the increase of laser scan speed. It was also found that simultaneously increasing (or decreasing) the laser power and the laser scan speed leads to the drastic change of melt pool aspect ratio (MPAR), and this in turn affects the competitive growth of stray grains. Overall, a larger MPAR was found to suppress the growth of stray grains more significantly. Three stray grain growth mechanisms, namely, promotive growth, suppressive growth, and neutral growth, were discovered and analyzed.

In investigating the engulfment/push behavior of nanoparticles in the solidification process of meta alloys, a phase-field approach was established to simulate the dendrite growth and predict local solidification front velocity. By estimating the critical engulf velocity from a non-steady-state front/particle model, the engulfment/pushing behavior as well as the final distribution of nanoparticles were able to be analyzed. The approach also allows the calculation of the Orowan bowing and the coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) mismatch strengthening effects induced from external nanoparticles. It was found that a smaller particle size results in a drastically higher critical front velocity, making the engulfment of nanoparticles more difficult. Push region is mainly located in the edge area of dendrite arms, because these areas usually have small solidification velocity, which favors the pushing of nanoparticles. A higher cooling rate results in alleviated pushing and thus a more uniform distribution of nanoparticles.

In addition, SLM experiments were adopted to produce specimens such as Inconel 718 and and its composites with reinforcements such as graphene nanoplatelet and titanium carbide. With the help of various material characterization methods, the effects of process parameters were studied, and the role of nanoparticles was investigated. The experimental results were used for supporting the modeling works.

The project provided the research training opportunities for graduate students at the University of Cincinnati (UC). In sequence, four graduate students were partially supported by this project. One Ph.D. student successfully defended his thesis in 2018. Two additional graduate students were involved in related activities. Also, the project allowed the PI to participate in the UC WISE (Women in Science and Engineering) - Summer Research Opportunities for Undergraduate Women program in summer 2016. One undergraduate woman student was recruited to the program under the PI?s supervision. The experience motivated her to remain at UC for graduate study. Meanwhile, the project contributed to the development and offering of the first graduate level course dedicated to additive manufacturing (AM) at UC, namely, MECH 7080 ?Metal Additive Manufacturing ? Principles and Process Modeling?. The course has been offered every academic year since Spring 2018. In addition, the project contributed to the establishment of a new graduate program, ?Master of Engineering in Additive Manufacturing?, at UC in 2018.

The project results were disseminated in the following ways: (1) presentations to industry - the PI has presented the findings to multiple manufacturing companies such as GE Aviation, Mazak USA, and Makino USA since 2016; (2) presentations at technical conferences such as Advanced & Additive Manufacturing Talent Summit at Miami University (Oxford, OH) in 2017, NSF workshop on Accelerating NSF Research in Additive Manufacturing toward Industrial Applications in 2017, TMS Annual Meeting & Exhibition in 2018, and SME's North American Manufacturing Research Conference (NAMRC) in 2018; (3) class teaching for the undergraduate and graduate students in MECH 2060 Manufacturing Processes and MECH 7080 at UC since 2017; and (4) research community by publishing papers with leading technical journals.

 


Last Modified: 08/24/2020
Modified by: Jing Shi
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The project has enabled modeling and simulation methods that allow for realistic prediction, process design and optimization of laser melting additive processes. The results have contributed to the fundamental understanding of fast solidification process in laser additive manufacturing of metal alloys. A multi-scale modeling approach was developed to investigate the dendrite morphology, solute redistribution, interdendritic micro-segregation, and stray grain growth during selective laser melting (SLM). The approach consists of (1) meso-scale finite element analysis (FEA) for calculating the temperature field, and (2) micro-scale phase field (PF) method for modeling solidification evolution in the SLM process. It was discovered that the effects of SLM process parameters on various cooling characteristics of the melt pool, including the cooling rate, thermal gradient/solidification rate ratio, and slope of solidification front, are significant. Due to the ultra-fast cooling rate, solute trapping plays a significant role in the solidification process and therefore the interdendritic segregation is alleviated with the increase of laser scan speed. It was also found that simultaneously increasing (or decreasing) the laser power and the laser scan speed leads to the drastic change of melt pool aspect ratio (MPAR), and this in turn affects the competitive growth of stray grains. Overall, a larger MPAR was found to suppress the growth of stray grains more significantly. Three stray grain growth mechanisms, namely, promotive growth, suppressive growth, and neutral growth, were discovered and analyzed. In investigating the engulfment/push behavior of nanoparticles in the solidification process of meta alloys, a phase-field approach was established to simulate the dendrite growth and predict local solidification front velocity. By estimating the critical engulf velocity from a non-steady-state front/particle model, the engulfment/pushing behavior as well as the final distribution of nanoparticles were able to be analyzed. The approach also allows the calculation of the Orowan bowing and the coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) mismatch strengthening effects induced from external nanoparticles. It was found that a smaller particle size results in a drastically higher critical front velocity, making the engulfment of nanoparticles more difficult. Push region is mainly located in the edge area of dendrite arms, because these areas usually have small solidification velocity, which favors the pushing of nanoparticles. A higher cooling rate results in alleviated pushing and thus a more uniform distribution of nanoparticles. In addition, SLM experiments were adopted to produce specimens such as Inconel 718 and and its composites with reinforcements such as graphene nanoplatelet and titanium carbide. With the help of various material characterization methods, the effects of process parameters were studied, and the role of nanoparticles was investigated. The experimental results were used for supporting the modeling works. The project provided the research training opportunities for graduate students at the University of Cincinnati (UC). In sequence, four graduate students were partially supported by this project. One Ph.D. student successfully defended his thesis in 2018. Two additional graduate students were involved in related activities. Also, the project allowed the PI to participate in the UC WISE (Women in Science and Engineering) - Summer Research Opportunities for Undergraduate Women program in summer 2016. One undergraduate woman student was recruited to the program under the PI?s supervision. The experience motivated her to remain at UC for graduate study. Meanwhile, the project contributed to the development and offering of the first graduate level course dedicated to additive manufacturing (AM) at UC, namely, MECH 7080 ?Metal Additive Manufacturing ? Principles and Process Modeling?. The course has been offered every academic year since Spring 2018. In addition, the project contributed to the establishment of a new graduate program, ?Master of Engineering in Additive Manufacturing?, at UC in 2018. The project results were disseminated in the following ways: (1) presentations to industry - the PI has presented the findings to multiple manufacturing companies such as GE Aviation, Mazak USA, and Makino USA since 2016; (2) presentations at technical conferences such as Advanced & Additive Manufacturing Talent Summit at Miami University (Oxford, OH) in 2017, NSF workshop on Accelerating NSF Research in Additive Manufacturing toward Industrial Applications in 2017, TMS Annual Meeting & Exhibition in 2018, and SME's North American Manufacturing Research Conference (NAMRC) in 2018; (3) class teaching for the undergraduate and graduate students in MECH 2060 Manufacturing Processes and MECH 7080 at UC since 2017; and (4) research community by publishing papers with leading technical journals.
